controls.title: The web server must use HTTP/2, at a minimum.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Protect the confidentiality and/or integrity of transmitted information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The web server must use HTTP/2, at a minimum.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure the web server to use HTTP/2, at a minimum. 

Note that browsers support HTTP/2 only in HTTPS mode. The tunneling of HTTP/1.x through HTTPS is not an approved configuration.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
HTTP/2, like HTTPS, enhances security compared to HTTP/1.x by minimizing the risk of header-based attacks (e.g., header injection and manipulation).

Websites that fully utilize HTTP/2 are inherently protected and defend against smuggling attacks. HTTP/2 provides the method for specifying the length of a request, which removes any potential for ambiguity that can be leveraged by an attacker. 

This is applicable to all web architectures such as load balancing/proxy use cases. 
- The front-end and back-end servers should both be configured to use HTTP/2.
- HTTP/2 must be used for communications between web servers.
- Browser vendors have agreed to only support HTTP/2 only in HTTPS mode, thus TLS must be configured to meet this requirement. TLS configuration is out of scope for this requirement.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: The web server must disable HTTP/1.x downgrading.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Protect the confidentiality and/or integrity of transmitted information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The web server must disable HTTP/1.x downgrading.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure the web server to disable HTTP/1.x downgrading.

If HTTP downgrading is operationally necessary, validate the rewritten request against the HTTP/1.1 specification, i.e., reject requests that contain new lines in the headers, colons in header names, and spaces in the request method.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
HTTP/2 is backward compatible with HTTP/1.x, so it is possible to configure the architecture to implement a front-end server for HTTP/2 while communicating with one or more back-end servers that support only HTTP/1.x. Thus, the front end effectively has to translate or downgrade the requests it receives into the less secure protocol. HTTP downgrading negates the benefits of HTTP/2.

If HTTP downgrading cannot be avoided, validate the rewritten/downgraded request against the HTTP/1.1 specification. For example, reject requests that contain newlines in the headers, colons in header names, and spaces in the request method.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: The web server must interpret and normalize ambiguous HTTP requests or terminate the TCP connection.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Checks the validity of organization-defined information inputs to the system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The web server must interpret and normalize ambiguous HTTP requests or terminate the TCP connection.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure the web server to interpret HTTP headers so they are normalized and unambiguous. The web server must validate requests that report message body as "zero" in the HTTP header.

Configure the web server to drop ambiguous requests that cannot be normalized and terminate the TCP connection.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Request smuggling attacks involve placing both the Content-Length header and the Transfer-Encoding header into a single HTTP/1 request and manipulating it so that web servers (i.e., back-end, front-end, load balancers) process the request differently. There are a number of variants of this type of attack with different names. However, all variants are addressed by configuring the front-end server to exclusively use HTTP/2 when communicating with other web servers. Specific instances of this vulnerability can be resolved by reconfiguring the front-end server to normalize ambiguous requests before routing them onward.  However, if the request cannot be made unambiguous or normalized, configure both the front-end and back-end servers to reject the message and close the connection.

It is important to not assume requests do not have a body. For all web servers, examine requests that report message body length as zero in the HTTP header and drop the request.

For load balancing or reverse proxying implementation:
-The front-end web server must interpret and forward HTTP requests, such that the back-end server receives a consistent interpretation of the request, or terminate the TCP connection.
-The back-end web server must drop ambiguous requests that cannot be normalized and terminate the TCP connection.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: The web server must terminate the connection if server-level exceptions are triggered when handling requests to prevent HTTP request smuggling attacks.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Checks the validity of organization-defined information inputs to the system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The web server must terminate the connection if server-level exceptions are triggered when handling requests to prevent HTTP request smuggling attacks.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Configure web server to terminate the connection if server-level exceptions are triggered when handling requests to prevent HTTP request smuggling attacks.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
The web server defines a set of exceptions for every HTTP status code. Each exception class has a status code according to RFC 2068: Codes with 100-300 are not really errors; 400s are client errors, and 500s are server errors. If not directly specified, headers will be added to the default response headers.

In the event of an anomaly or exception during the processing of requests, it is safer to terminate the connection to prevent malformed requests from exploiting potential protocol vulnerabilities.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: The web server must only use forward proxies that route HTTP/2 requests upstream.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Protect the confidentiality and/or integrity of transmitted information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The web server must only use forward proxies that route HTTP/2 requests upstream.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Configure the web server to only use forward proxies that route HTTP/2 requests upstream.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Without protection of the transmitted information, confidentiality and integrity may be compromised since unprotected communications can be intercepted and read or altered. Communication paths outside the physical protection of a controlled boundary are exposed to the possibility of interception and modification. 

It is crucial that the web server and forward proxy agree about the boundaries between requests. Otherwise, an attacker may be able to send ambiguous and other smuggling attacks to the web server.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.
